title: Module 2
description: This quiz covers the key benefits of investing, including how investing supports long-term goals, how it compares to saving, why starting early matters, and how investment growth helps you achieve bigger financial dreams.

questions.question: Saving is usually for short-term goals.
questions.explanation: Saving is meant for short-term needs—like buying something soon or keeping money safe for emergencies. Savings grow slowly, so they’re best when you need the money within a few months or a couple of years.

questions.question: Investing is usually for long-term goals.
questions.explanation: Investing is designed for long-term goals because it gives your money time to grow. Over many years, investments can increase in value much more than a savings account, making them perfect for big future goals like a car, university, or building wealth.

questions.question: What is one benefit of investing compared to putting all your money in a savings account?
options: Investing has the potential to earn higher returns
Saving makes your money double automatically
Investing means you don’t need a plan
questions.explanation: Savings accounts earn low interest, while investments—like stocks—can grow much faster. This helps your money work harder for you.

questions.question: Why do people start investing at a young age?
options: Because teens must invest by law
Because saving only works after age 30
Because starting early gives money more time to grow
Because investing is only for teenagers
questions.explanation: The earlier you invest, the longer your money has to grow through compounding. Even small amounts invested early can become much larger over time.

questions.question: What makes investing useful for future dreams like buying a car, university costs, or starting a business?
options: Investing replaces the need to save
Investing helps your money grow enough to reach big goals
questions.explanation: Investing builds your wealth over many years. This growth helps you afford larger goals that saving alone might not reach.
